column1: EIGHT years before he had seen his friend off at the North Wall and wished him godspeed.
column3: You could tell that at once by his travelled air, his well-cut tweed suit, and fearless accent.
column4: Few fellows had talents like his and fewer still could remain unspoiled by such success.
column5: Gallaher's heart was in the right place and he had deserved to win.
column6: It was something to have a friend like that.
column7: Little Chandler's thoughts ever since lunch-time had been of his meeting with Gallaher, of Gallaher's invitation and of the great city London where Gallaher lived.
column8: He was called Little Chandler because, though he was but slightly under the average stature, he gave one the idea of being a little man.
column9: His hands were white and small, his frame was fragile, his voice was quiet and his manners were refined.
column10: He took the greatest care of his fair silken hair and moustache and used perfume discreetly on his handkerchief.
column11: The half-moons of his nails were perfect and when he smiled you caught a glimpse of a row of childish white teeth.
